`,(0,e.jsx)(n.p,{children:"The Orange Pi 5 MAX is an exciting new single-board computer (SBC) that follows in the footsteps of its predecessor, the Orange Pi 5 Pro, while maintaining the same form factor as the Raspberry Pi 5. In this article, we'll dive into the details of the Orange Pi 5 MAX, exploring its various components, performance benchmarks, and practical use cases."}),`
`,(0,e.jsxs)(n.h2,{id:"operating-system-compatibility",children:[(0,e.jsx)(n.a,{"aria-hidden":"true",tabIndex:"-1",href:"#operating-system-compatibility",children:(0,e.jsx)(n.span,{className:"icon icon-link"})}),"Operating System Compatibility"]}),`
`,(0,e.jsxs)(n.p,{children:["Orange Pi offers a wide variety of operating systems for the 5 MAX, which can be downloaded directly from their ",(0,e.jsx)(n.a,{href:"http://www.orangepi.org/html/hardWare/computerAndMicrocontrollers/service-and-support/Orange-Pi-5-Max.html",children:"website"}),". These include popular Linux distributions like Ubuntu, Debian, and Arch Linux, as well as an Android image. Additionally, there\u2019s ",(0,e.jsx)(n.a,{href:"https://github.com/Joshua-Riek/ubuntu-rockchip",children:"Ubuntu for Rockchip"}),", an open-source project that supports Rockchip SoCs, providing builds specifically for the ",(0,e.jsx)(n.a,{href:"https://joshua-riek.github.io/ubuntu-rockchip-download/boards/orangepi-5-max.html",children:"Orange Pi 5 MAX"}),"."]}),`
`,(0,e.jsx)(n.p,{children:"While I initially wanted to run Armbian Linux on this board, support for it isn't available yet."}),`
`,(0,e.jsx)(n.p,{children:(0,e.jsx)(n.strong,{children:"Update: 26th Sept 2024"})}),`
`,(0,e.jsx)(n.p,{children:"A community build image is available. The desktop build is currently not working properly while the server build image works fine. But currently I haven't tested the entire build."}),`
`,(0,e.jsxs)(n.h2,{id:"initial-setup-and-desktop-performance",children:[(0,e.jsx)(n.a,{"aria-hidden":"true",tabIndex:"-1",href:"#initial-setup-and-desktop-performance",children:(0,e.jsx)(n.span,{className:"icon icon-link"})}),"Initial Setup and Desktop Performance"]}),`
`,(0,e.jsx)(n.p,{children:"To get started, I installed the Debian image from Orange Pi onto a microSD card for testing. The overall desktop experience was quite smooth, with quick load times for web browsers, minimal lag when moving windows, and overall responsiveness."}),`
`,(0,e.jsx)(n.div,{children:(0,e.jsx)(i,{alt:"desktop",src:"/static/images/2024/orange-pi-5-max/desktop.webp",width:"1920",height:"1080"})}),`
`,(0,e.jsx)(n.p,{children:"I tested media performance by running a 1080p YouTube video, which played smoothly after a few initial frame drops. Switching to 4K resolution yielded similarly smooth results, with no frame drops throughout playback."}),`
`,(0,e.jsx)(n.div,{children:(0,e.jsx)(i,{alt:"youtube",src:"/static/images/2024/orange-pi-5-max/youtube-performance.webp",width:"1920",height:"1080"})}),`
`,(0,e.jsx)(n.p,{children:"Impressively, all of these tests were conducted without using a fan or heatsink, meaning the system ran completely silent."}),`
`,(0,e.jsxs)(n.h2,{id:"nvme-performance",children:[(0,e.jsx)(n.a,{"aria-hidden":"true",tabIndex:"-1",href:"#nvme-performance",children:(0,e.jsx)(n.span,{className:"icon icon-link"})}),"NVMe Performance"]}),`
`,(0,e.jsx)(n.p,{children:"One of the highlights of the Orange Pi 5 MAX is its support for PCIe Gen 3 via a 2280 NVMe slot. After installing an NVMe drive in the M.2 M-key slot, I initially saw transfer speeds of around 220 MB/s. However, after formatting the drive with the Ext4 file system, the speeds jumped to 2,300 MB/s\u2014nearly three times faster than the Raspberry Pi 5, which only supports PCIe Gen 2 with a single lane."}),`
`,(0,e.jsx)(n.div,{children:(0,e.jsx)(i,{alt:"nvme",src:"/static/images/2024/orange-pi-5-max/nvme.webp",width:"1920",height:"1080"})}),`
`,(0,e.jsxs)(n.p,{children:["Although I expected speeds closer to 3,900 MB/s, which is the theoretical maximum for PCIe Gen 3 with four lanes, I confirmed via the ",(0,e.jsx)(n.code,{children:"lspci"})," command that the board was indeed running at PCIe Gen 3 speeds. The takeaway? The Orange Pi 5 MAX offers much faster NVMe speeds than its competitors, and you don\u2019t need an additional hat to achieve them."]}),`
`,(0,e.jsx)(n.div,{children:(0,e.jsx)(i,{alt:"lscpi",src:"/static/images/2024/orange-pi-5-max/lscpi.webp",width:"1920",height:"1080"})}),`

`,(0,e.jsxs)(n.p,{children:["Given my interest in home automation, I set up Docker and ran Home Assistant on the board. It worked flawlessly, allowing easy access to the Home Assistant UI. I also tested voice assistants by running Whisper and Piper containers for speech-to-text conversion. The Orange Pi 5 MAX processed speech-to-text in 4 seconds, while the Raspberry Pi 5 took about 14 seconds using the same ",(0,e.jsx)(n.code,{children:"small-int8"})," model. Using a smaller ",(0,e.jsx)(n.code,{children:"tiny-int8"})," model, the 5 MAX completed the task in 1.2 seconds\u2014twice as fast as the Raspberry Pi 5."]}),`
